The sense of smell, or olfaction, begins with olfactory receptors located in the nasal cavity. <[silence]> These receptors detect airborne molecules and send signals to the brain for processing. <[silence]> Humans possess approximately 400 types of olfactory receptors, each sensitive to different odor molecules. <[silence]> This diversity allows for the detection of a vast array of scents. <[silence]> 

Once the olfactory receptors capture scent molecules, the signals travel along the olfactory nerve to the olfactory bulb in the brain. <[silence]> The olfactory bulb processes these signals and forwards them to various brain regions, including the limbic system. <[silence]> This connection explains why smells often evoke strong emotions and memories. <[silence]> The sense of smell is unique in its direct link to the brain's emotional and memory centers. <[silence]> 

Pheromones are chemical signals that influence social and reproductive behaviors in many species. <[silence]> In humans, the role of pheromones is less pronounced but still under investigation. <[silence]> Some studies suggest they may affect mood and interpersonal attraction. <[silence]> The subtlety of pheromone influence in humans highlights the complexity of olfactory communication. <[silence]> 

Odor memories can be remarkably vivid and long-lasting. <[silence]> This phenomenon occurs because olfactory information is processed in the same brain areas responsible for memory and emotion. <[silence]> Smells can trigger memories from decades past, underscoring the powerful connection between scent and personal history. <[silence]> The interplay between olfaction and memory is a subject of ongoing research. <[silence]>
